othermaciej: very cool to see Wildfox message about SVG filters support
MikeSmith: oh?
on webkit-dev
SVG filters are PURE GOLD
i liek the whole displacement mapping thing best
erlehmann: is that because of mariocart? http://www.tapper-ware.net/stable/PerspectiveWith6LinesOfXML-CanvasEnhanced/index.xhtml
shepazu, that would be one example. but animated displacement maps (gif files) are fine too.
http://www.w3.org/2001/tag/doc/content-to-apps.html
2001? That's an old document
Since when did dates in W3C URIs mean anything?
Since humans started extracting obvious patterns and meaning from text that they read
annevk: yt? what spec should define how the 'abort' event fires when the "unload a document" algorithm for the xhr's browsing context's document is run, if any?
hmm, prolly XHR :/
well, which abort event?
apparently (I haven't tested) 'abort' fires on XHR objects that are pending when the document is unloaded
i really need a better term for "first script"
responsible script?
or something like that
what's special about the first script?
I see
the similar concept in WebKit is "dynamic global object"
the dynamic global object is the one where a particular nested chunk of script execution began
"first script" is not a great term, since an event listener is a function, not a script
"code entry-point" seems like a needlessly obscure term for a "function"
functions are also not necessarily associated at all with a script, in the sense of a <script> element anyway
it would be better to skip right to the global object from the function and bypass the concept of "script"
code entry-point doesn't mean function
e.g. <script>/*this is a code entry-point*/</script>
it's not really to do with the global object either
e.g. the script's base URL can be different for two scripts with the same global object
how?
<script xml:base="a">...</script><script xml:base="b">...</script>
do browsers actually use the "script's base URL" as defined there, rather than the base URL of the script's global object's browsing context's active document?
oh actually that's not true, my bad
what doing relative URL resolution for window.open for instance?
no you're right
the spec just has script's base URL as being a shorthand way of saying that
i suppose i could remember the global object instead of the script and call it the dynamic global object
I'm not sure "dynamic global object" will be more clear to people necessarily, that was just a cite of our usage
we contrast it with the "lexical global object" which is the one where the currently running function was initially defined
yeah i don't know if it's better enough to be worth it
"first script" is confusing people though
fwiw "dynamic global object" as a set of words doesn't really convey anything to me
I'm just saying that the "script" notion does not really add a useful abstraction, in terms of what actually needs to happen
jgraham: that's a good thing, compared to "first script", which conveys something wrong. :-)
"outermost global object" would perhaps be better in context, though it might connote outermost frame instead of outermost in the sense of execution nesting
othermaciej: it's a useful abstraction because there are three kinds of global objects (Window, WorkerGlobalScope, and the empty object)
is there some term referring to the first stack frame?
which we could adopt here?
othermaciej: (though it could certainly be phrased in a different way than it is now)
too verbose but likely unambiguous: outermost script execution entry point
entry script?
might be better than first script, at any rate
"first script
" sounds too much like the first one that appears in the page
right
is there any way in which an impotent script's base URL can be used?
I think the answer is no so the empty object case doesn't matter
anyway, "entry" might have less chance of producing confusion
there isn't, and indeed its script's base URL is explicitly not set currently
anyway, i'll leave this stuff for now
websockets next, and then i'm ready for webapps LCs
only 61 websocket e-mails
looks at http://dev.w3.org/2009/dap/camera/Overview.html and wonders why <input type=image> as specced in html5 isn't enough
(for what that api can do)
Hixie, presumably, you mean, <input type=file>?
uh yes
Hixie: because not everything is about grabbing a static image, deferring any control over the photo/film process to a native implementation

(I don't neccesarily completely agree with the approach in the spec, but <input type="file"> would be horribly insufficient, if you were to reimplent something like Layar, or the google turn-by-turn app from Android 2.0
certainly <input type=file> isn't the ultimate solution for everything
i just meant for doing what was in the api spec
two problems (which can probably be overcome
1) Media data from a device is not "files"
the main purpose of an API is to grab the data, not neccesarily for upload, but for later processing
<input type=file> exposes a URL the same way the API does, these days
2) <input type="file"> offers little control over the user interface, and would force the user to make an informed choice
the api doesn't give much control either
as written today
anyone know what the <figure/> tag mean
see the spec
the w3c page crashes my browser lol
is it for pictures and stuff
try the multipage version, it may crash your browser less
lol html5 sucks
That was insightful
IRC always is

Thanks, yeah.

thinking about it more I guess it's not quite clear
well, it depends on how you interpret things
ImageData is made accessible through an API...

oh well, I'm advocating <input type="file" for camera capture now
there's however a bit there about selecting a camera on clicking,
good approach for microdata?
jgraham: I suggest amputation
jgraham: I suggest writing the word as "puss-y" to avoid ambiguous connotations.

TabAtkins: I think that's <datagrid> which doesn't exist. I believe <datalist> does.
Datalist is alive and well (and implemented in Opera).

I'm going to apply to work at Opera, so I can help refine HTML5 and resume studying how authors use HTML, but I'm not sure if they have a job opening which fits that

BenMillard: Good luck! :)
and the troll of the day award goes to: http://twitter.com/slicknet/status/6276901024
http://twitter.com/slicknet/status/6278180943
reads http://edward.oconnor.cx/2009/12/RDFa-and-the-DOM
On the subject of text vs (DOM|Infoset|any sane model), see also http://github.com/msporny/rdfa-test-suite/commit/a27e4f4500a854024b0e3914af13f6227d54d805
wow, that was actually very well worth reading
which seems to suggest SAX parsers may get confused by thinking markup like <string> is identical to <string>
(Edward O'Connor, not the git commit...)
hmm, a well written commit message though, I never bother writing that much
It's a good explanation of the rationale behind the change, I just think the rationale is completely wrong and misguided :-)
I'm not sure I understand though
(and caused by thinking the raw byte stream is important)
why would seeing <strong> in a text node cause you to think that's an XML literal?

http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Nov/0099.html - "The first was an issue that would occur on SAX-based processors that did not have access to the raw byte stream and thus wouldn't be able to tell if the encoded "<strong>" value should be interpreted as an XML Literal or not."
foolip: It wouldn't
I just don't know enough about how XML Literals are encoded or how SAX parsers work to understand
but that's OK, because I have packing to do and am flying to Vietnam on Friday
yay me

They shouldn't be encoded at all - the idea is that when you're converting an element to a value, if it has child elements then you serialise the element's content into an XMLLiteral string, else you use the content as a typeless string
which is nice and easy when you consider XML documents to be a tree/stream of elements and text nodes
right
so how do "SAX-based processors that did not have access to the raw byte stream" see XML?
last time I used SAX for anything I was feeding it XML as a string and got parse events

but if you don't have that model then even the concept of "serialise the element's content" makes no sense, so it's sort of defined as copying the characters contained within the element, except munging it a bit to add namespace declarations, and also it needs canonicalisation, and the specification is really fuzzy
(or something along those lines)
SAX processors see a stream of startElement and endElement and characters events
(or something very similar to that)
oh, on that end
I was thinking backwards
of course
sounds like a problem very much not specific to RDFa though
I don't think there's a problem at all
Or, I don't think there's a problem at all with SAX
or with writing RDFa processors on top of a SAX processor
The only problem is the RDFa spec
what does it actually say to do produce an XML Literal?
(which is mostly specific to RDFa, not other specs)
pretend it has the raw byte stream, I presume
oh well

"The value of the [XML literal] is a string created by serializing to text, all nodes that are descendants of the [current element], i.e., not including the element itself, and giving it a datatype of rdf:XMLLiteral."
plus errata: "For the avoidance of doubt, this means in part that the current default namespace of each descendant element MUST also be included in the emitted XML literal."

plus errata: "Unfortunately, the requirements for such a serialized string are not completely clear when it comes to XML Namespaces. For the avoidance of doubt, in future versions of the RDFa Syntax Recommendation, we expect to indicate that the value of the XML literal SHOULD be serialized Exclusive Canonical XML as defined in [XMLEXC14N]. We advise current implementations to start supporting this use model now, since other participants in their XML tool ch
foolip: thanks
sounds like it assumes a DOM
Oh, so it does actually talk about serializing nodes
hober: oh there you are :)
Discussions about the namespace/c14n requirements and RDFa-in-text/html seem to indicate that many people don't believe in the DOM-like model, though
Anyway, I should probably stop complaining about this :-p
We probably all should
but while we're on the topic, I found this amusing: http://www.merttol.com/articles/web/understanding-rdfa.html
(see my comment at end)
I just hope that this whole RDFa issue doesn't have people hating *RDF*
Not at all
RDF is hated for its own unique reasons
RDF is too vague to be a proper target for hating
down with graphs!
Down with data structures!
Down with data!
PNG instead of HTML5?
foolip, that would put me and aobut 1,000,000 other people out of a job :(
s/aobut/about/
Poor Bobby McFerrin, doomed to never be a unique individual
Maybe RDFa will usher in a new age of less graphy RDF, one where almost all statements use string literals
Bonus points if you have RDFa embedded in markup inside string literals
workmad3, why are you here?
Sirisian_: just hovering :)
othermaciej: Well, turns out I already had an account, but it doesn't *look* like I have editting privileges.  I guess I'll wait for MikeSmith to show up in irc.
TabAtkins: I think Laura Carlson also has the power to enable editing - not sure who else
TabAtkins: I'm not really sure why the wiki is restricted in the first place - I'm not aware of any vandalism problems
Maybe there aren't any vandalism problems because it's restricted
Or maybe maciej doesn't consider offers on cheap airline tickets vandalism
TabAtkins: looks like you should already have editing rights according to the list
TabAtkins: in fact supposedly both of us have the right to grant editing rights - perhaps that is just done by editing the <http://esw.w3.org/topic/ESWEditorsGroup> page
othermaciej: Hrm.  It's telling me I don't have permission to edit this page, where "this page" is the new one I'm trying to create.
TabAtkins: unfortunately I don't really understand how the Wiki is managed
Yeah, me neither.  Shrug.
TabAtkins: I could paste in a copy of the document for you but I'm hesitant to put it in a place you can't edit
You could paste it in, with a link to the location on my server for "latest version"?
your account is named TabAtkins?
Yup
othermaciej: Now that I think about it, I editted the Taxi page before TPAC.  So I do have editting rights.  Perhaps I just don't have page creation rights.
If you can create the page for me I think it likely that I can edit it.
(Which would explain why I don't see a "Create Page" button around anywhere, and had to manually put a new page in the url.)
TabAtkins: ok - what would you like the page to be called?
I was attempting to call it Issue76CounterProposal, but use whatever you think is best.
That naming convention doesn't scale well if there's more than two proposals
Issue76StatusQuoChangeProposal?
